name: Cinders
description: A mature take on Cinderella that's all about player choices and breaking the classic fairy tale in any way you like.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista/7/8/10 Memory: 512 MB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 200 MB available space

reviews.review_text: The artwork is gorgeous, and the ability to skip anything you've already read before makes multiple playthroughs MUCH less of a hassle than youd expect. It's a retake on the classic fairytale, and I very much enjoy the multiple directions it can go! If you ever loved storybooks as a child (and you can set aside a few character flaws...) it's worth the time to indulge in Cinders' world.

I'm not really a big fan of visual novels, but I genuinely enjoyed this lovely little adaption of the Cinderella fairytale.  The artwork is gorgeous, and the music is lovely.  And in my opinion it was well-written too. I'm not going to spoiler the story with an elaborate breakdown. Just enjoy the magic of the moment.  Certainly a welcome introduction to visual novels. And also a good title for the complainers that think visual novels have too much anime. =^)

My opening statement:   Cinders  is pretty good visual novel. I think this is all you need to know at this point.  I like when familiar stories are reimagined, authors and creators give them they own flair and taste, and it worked in  Cinders . Story feels fresh, you can like (love would be strong term) and hate characters, and for 3 hours it grabs you and you want to see how the story ends. Happily ever after or miserable till death.  Art is simply fantastic, i am big fan of it.  Music could have been better.  There is nothing specific for what you can be harsh on this game and if you want me to cherry picking some stuff; I was surprised when i saw 16,99€ as a price for  Cinders . Holy cow! If i didn't get this game in bundle, i would never ever buy game like this, for price this high.  Awesome artwork, good storytelling were reasons to play till the end; but one end only.   Grade:   C   P.S. Gloria is hot. I am weird. I know. So what!

I originally had this game on my wishlist based on the art style alone. Turns out, it's a re-imagining of the tale of Cinderella. And it is a visual novel, where your choices have an actual impact on the story.   Graphics / art - 5/10  Let me get this out of the way since this is what first pulled me in. Mmmm ... not that impressive at the end of the day. Most of the characters look a little weird, and there's just not much animation. I know it's a visual novel, but it feels like they could have done a little more. So it's not bad, just not quite up to its potential in this area.   Story / characters - 8/10  The story itself is slightly adapted, and I have to say the developers did a great job. The wicked stepmother and the two evil stepsisters are actual characters with personalities, and through the story you can understand some of the reasons why they behave as they do. Truly a tremendous spin on a stale old tale.  The developers also get into why there is a ball, which is pretty interesting.  The most annoying character is probably Cinders herself. In some ways she behaves like any normal person in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation would. However, other times she's a bit whiny and preachy.  My favorite character was actually the stepmother. She's less of a demon when you get to know her reasoning and motivations. And her drive is impressive.  The side characters beyond the main ones (Cinders and her step-family being the core characters), are less interesting, and it seems like there are some interesting mysteries into their backgrounds that unfortunately don't get fleshed out. Like what the relationship is between Cinder's mother and some of the other side characters. What happened to Cinder's mother?   Gameplay - 10/10  As with most visual novels, it's mostly reading. However, at key points you get to make decisions. I wish I had read about the game before playing to better appreciate the impact of decisions. It would have let me know how important it is to use all of your (I think) 10 save slots so that you don't have to restart the story from the beginning to find all the endings.  Basically, you can be good, neutral or evil based on your decisions. And your decisions impact your route to the ball, which suitor you end up with, and whether you're even happy at the end. I overwrote a lot of my old saves as I went along, so I was really limited in my endings. However, I think there are a total of about 12 variations.  Pretty incredible, eh? The game itself isn't amazing, but when you realize how the developers freshened up the source material, you can't help but be impressed!  8/10

Cinders is a realistic retelling of the classic Cinderella story. It's like a visual novel with a whole lot of reading (obviously), but it also gives you a choice from time to time. Choices that affect the story. As a result there are several endings to be unlocked, and a single playthrough can take anywhere between 3-5 hours I think. The art is done remarkably well, even if the faces lack of bit of character and the whole thing feels very polished. Except for a few typos, that is.   I would recommend it to everyone who knows the story or just likes reading. But please note that it's not so much a game, but more of an interactive book. There's very little input required. And let's not forget about the price which is absurdly high. So for now I suggest waiting for a sale.  [Rating: 73/100]

Amazing game, and I say that as someone who doesn't normally play visual novels because: a) they are usually drawn in the style of anime, and b) they are usually dating sims -- I find neither of those two things particularly appealing. This game, however, is not even close to being a dating sim (although there are different romance options you can choose to pursue) and the art style is miles away from anime and very beautiful.  The story is a retelling of the Cinderella fairytale with a lot more depth, featuring well-rounded characters, complicated familial relations and meaningful choices. It emphasizes the extent to which characters' personal choices are limited by/the product of their circumstances and surroundings. The wicked stepmother and stepsisters are not simple archetypal chracters but complex figures with motivations and agendas that arise from their life circumstances. The main character Cinders, the young woman who lives as a servant in her own house, is trying to take destiny in her own hands and break free from her current circumstances, but cannot do so without outside help. The game makes a point: despite her desire to be independent and have agency, her available options are nevertheless to some extent the product of particular conditions that are outside of her influence (of her father marrying as he did, of her mother ensuring Cinders gets help when she needs it, etc).   The writting is very good and the choices in the game are meaningful; I found replaying the game to explore different results very interesting. The first playthrough takes about 3 hours, while subsequent playthroughs can be made a lot shorter as there's an option to skip through dialogues that you've read in previous playthroughs.   Definitely recommended for people who love good stories and don't mind reading a bunch.

I recieved Cinders as a gift, and it has become one of my favorite visual novels of the year. The story follows that of Cinderella in a more mature light. The art and soundtrack is stunningly beautiful. It has an overall touching story, and I found myself able to eventually understand each of the characters despite the limited interactions. I can't possibly say that there are any cons.

Cinders is very much an interactive novel more than it is a game. By biggest gripe is that whilst you do make choices that can alter the storyline and the ending, there isn't much variation aside from a few scenes playing out differently and a different set of text showing up for the ending 'cutscene'.  But other than that it is a well crafted title. The art work is good and unlike similar games the characters have some (albeit limited) animation. Since you will probably play through the game multiple times there is a very useful function that allows you to quickly skip through dialogue you have already seen, stopping at anything that is new and at any choice you have to make.  If you are a fan of reading and fairy tales you will probably enjoy the game. If a wall of text sends you in to a fit of rage then you should probably avoid this one. Overall I'd give it a thumbs up.

PROS - Cinders's personality is up to the player via dialogue choices --> Consistency is rewarded, while random personality choices don't serve as well - The art is beautiful, from the backgrounds to the characters - Morality is ambiguous, unlike what you expect from fairy tales - 4 different endings, all with many variations - The dialogue flows well and is interesting to follow - The stepsisters and stepmother are relatable, vulnerable people with real problems - Branches in the storyline feel like they matter for the events that happen no matter what - Two different forces of magic can help Cinders for the ball --> Both have a connection with Cinders's mother and provide different background info respectively - All the characters have issues to work out, the relationships Cinders makes from the player choices feel like they develop in a realistic way; nothing feels forced, like in the fairy tale - 3 different goals for Cinders, not just marrying the prince and living happily ever after - 3 different love interests - Can re-watch endings and variations after you unlock them, very high replay value - Skip function for dialogue you have already read - No tedious stat building!! :)  CONS - Cinders's name... It's a bit difficult to take a scene seriously sometimes when characters call her 'Cinders' - The game doesn't tell you what personality you have stacked or what progress your relationships are...so sometimes it's hard to know how to progress and confusing if a certain dialogue option doesn't work --> Leads to lots of trial and error - Failing to get the variation you want can be a bit frustrating for completionists - The music isn't too memorable - No homosexual romances, all 3 love interests are male - No customization of how Cinders looks - No voices  This is a wonderful, extensive visual novel and possibly one of the best I've ever played. I've always criticized Cinderella as a character for being one of the most passive protagonists in the history of fairy tales, but in this game you can make her to be the woman you always wanted her to be. She also doesn't always have to marry the prince and sometimes the ending isn't going to be happy. You could even die and have no one mourn over you. The possibilities are vast, giving it lots of replay value. All the art is gorgeous to look at as well so oftentimes I just stop reading and take in the scene.  The developers were right in advertising this game as a 'mature' take on the fairy tale, as all the characters are ambiguous. You can never truly figure each of them out and most of the time, they will surprise you. The game does a wonderful job of consistently claiming that no one is so simple as 'good' or 'evil' and even the kingdom is going through a metamorphosis if you pay attention to the Prince's plot. Speaking of which, the writing is downright brilliant and atmospheric since it is a western visual novel. There are unfortunately no voices, but little nuances in what the characters say give your imagination plenty to give the characters voices of your own.  If you enjoy visual novels with emphasis on dialogue choices, protagonist identity, relationships, and no stat building, definitely buy this game. I hate tedious stat building myself and much prefer making decisions through dialogue. All relationships are accessible provided you have made the choices to develop them; they don't rely on you being 'cute' enough or 'intelligent' enough. Despite my glowing recommendation however, Cinders is by no means perfect and I eagerly await anything else the developers have building off of this amazing genre.

All around one of the best independent narrative-based games around. The art and music are on par with larger-production houses, and the game mechanics keep the story running smoothly. The team would have benefited greatly from a writer to punch up some of the dialogue, but all-in-all an interesting take on the classic Cinderella story.

btw my steam time-played is wrong   A fantasy story told through the lens of an adult reality, very interesting.   In execution Cinders is a model of how  visual novels  should be done. Cinders is not much of a choose-your-own-adventure because it is very linear, but your choices do influence most of the dialogue & interactions throughout the game. The multitude of choices leads to large variety in outcomes so you can comfortably do many playthroughs. The art is nice but somewhat limited (not a big deal), same again for the music.  Not exactly touchpad friendly because the hitbox will sometimes glitch and pick the wrong option. So use a mouse or use the autosave function to immeidately go back one choice when the wrong option is mischosen.   Recommended when on sale.

This is my FAVORITE STEAM GAME EVER!!! The choices are meaningful, it explores the complexity of family abuse, child raising, sibling rivalry, classism, reputation... it's the most REAL exploration of a 'fairy tale' I've ever seen! And there aren't any excuses thrown around to justify having only-white characters- there's actually people of color (well, Madame Ghede, who is amazing) and every. single. character. is made real and given life. After a few play-throughs you really get a feel for WHO Cinders is, who her sisters and stepmother are, even who her dead mother and dead father were, PLUS all the romance options, AND the prince, and even side characters who are just townspeople!   I would scream with joy if this company/group made an entire serious of games just like Cinders, but exploring the other fairy tales... Snow White, Rapunzel, the Snow Queen by HCA, AS MANY AS POSSIBLE. Then they could start bundling them and selling them as packs. Just a suggestion... or more of a heartfelt wish.  Normally $20 is too much to pay for a game, but I ASSURE YOU that this game is WORTH IT!!! I played it for hours and hours and hours and I still never got every single ending!   And the game is NOT just a dating sim- who you make Cinders, her values, her beliefs, her choices- these all have long term implications for the nation, the ruling family, HER family, and her life. But the dating is pretty fun, I gotta say!

Unique take on a classic story, beautiful graphics, and several different endings depending on choices made throughout gameplay. Some arguments between characters can carry on a bit too long, but that's a minor flaw compared to all the positives. Overall this is a fantastic game, and definitely worth the price.

Based on the ancient fairy tale of Cinderella, the visual novel  Cinders  tells a similar story of everybody's favourite soot-covered girl struggling under the oppressive yoke of her step-family. Playing as Cinders, who got this nickname from her deceased father because of her flaming red hair, you finally get to have a hand in your own fate. Develop your own personality, from kind and smart to Machiavellian and downright evil. Will you try to understand your stepmother and stepsisters and repair your relationship with them or are you looking to give them a taste of their own medicine? Will you pursue the handsome prince, flirt with your childhood friend, or even charm the captain of the guard?  Or perhaps romance is not what you're looking for, and you'd rather re-acquire your family's estate... Anything is possible!    Pros

Definitely recommend this! 10/10  + Amazing story-line that takes a mature & dark spin on the fairytale (and mockingly refers to it sometimes) + very worthwhile, thought-provoking dialogue to read through  + MANY variations, so there's a lot of re-play value + I really like the option to press 'ctrl' in order to Fast Forward through dialogue that you already have read (assuming you're doing a second playthrough) - best of all, it stops exactly where the new dialogue begins (assuming you made different choices), very handy and helps you not be bored by multiple playthroughs!  - a few spelling/grammar errors but MoaCube is aware of that and cataloguing these mistakes     here.

Lovely art, above-average writing, some replay value.   One of the most impressive things that sets this apart from other visual novels (from any country) is the incredible attention to detail. The fonts, text boxes, and interfaces are attractive and professional-looking; dynamic lighting makes the already-gorgeous backgrounds look even better; and characters' eyes actually move back and forth (although this sometimes can cause character models to veer into 'uncanny valley' territory).  My only real complaint is that, on one or two occasions, the parts of a conversation that were affected by my choices and the parts that would have been said regardless (i.e. main plot stuff) did not flow together naturally, making it difficult to determine whether the relationship between my protagonist and a particular character was friendly or hostile.  Still definitely in the upper-tier of visual novels. If you like VNs, this is a quality product and likely worth your time.

I played at this game really fast.  The artwork is beautiful, the settings have a magic atmosphere. The plot deviates from the classic fable, thank to psychological traits, also. When you're playing, if you have a lot of immagination, you can feel relaxed. The soundtrack helps this magic atmosphere to make you feel good.  Lastly, the main characters are well planned and, during the game, they don't lose their original attitude.

This game is fantastic! The art is beautiful (like many have said), I wanted to learn more about the characters, and I want to play it again! My friend and I played this simultaneously and arrived at very different conclusions, and even getting the same 'ending' can have variations within.   There are also many small details, like the slight movements in the background and characters' eyes, and how the text sounds different depending on the character that is speaking. I can see many more hours going into this game, no regrets!

I bought this game after watching a few YouTubers play it, which might affect my view on its replayability. While it can be replayed numerous times, some of the choices felt like they gave the same effect. Of course, this is to be expected sometimes with this genre of game. I really enjoy 'choose your own story' games, so I did like this. Cinders is beautifully illustrated, it has a fascinating story, and some cool achievements. I think I have played it through completely around eight times total, and everytime I did enjoy it. However, I am glad you have the ability to skip chunks of text, as a lot of them end up being the same.

95% dialogue, would like to see more animation/player choices, but my first run earned me the grim skull achievement aka die a miserable death which was surprising. Went back and ended up running off with hot scar-face Captain, much better ending. Beautiful art design

Wow... I bought this game a while ago and only recently got around to playing and have to say i'm impressed. Having played copious amounts of VNs in the past (and present, they are a guilty pleasure of mine, afterall), I was surprised with how many options and endings were available to the player to affect the story. Usually there are a couple of options with some rather than others being the more 'important' ones that affect the story but here, it seems as if almost every option branches the story in another direction. You help guide Cinders and with the choices you pick, her personality changes and so does the outcomeof the tale. The 'evil' stepmother and stepsisters aren't as black or white in this case - everyone has a reason for doing what they do and the characters are humanized. You're forced to take into account not only the actions but the setting the characters are in; whether they do things considered good or bad, most of the times they're just trying to do the best they can do in that situation.  Okay so basically what I'm trying to say is yes you should get the game and try it out because its worth the money. They put a lot of time and efforst into this one and it shows :)

Cinders is a story that takes start on a classic fairytale, but quickly becomes something much more mature, realistic and interesting. It's a story about women, their choices, motives and personalities and how all this lead to very different lives and consequences. But more than that, it's a story about Cinders - smart, brave, kind and ambitious girl, who doesn't want to sit and wait for her happiness and prince who saves her, but rather takes her fate into her own hands.  The game is really replaying and roleplaying - all your choices have their consequences that may not appear now, but take place later, when you almost forgot about them, so chose wisely. You have many possibilities to turn story in your favor, every ending has many variants and sometimes its change the tone of an ending completely. Your Cinders can be kind and modest, wise and bold, egoistic and rude - all this changes the story that you'll see. I really recomend you to try and play, especially if you fan of visual novels or choices and consequences games. Cinders really worth a shot. And it has marvellous strong female characters, something that we don't see often, sadly.

This is a beautiful visual novel. The backgrounds and subtle animations make it come to life. There is a colorful cast of characters that I enjoyed interacting with.  I've played through 4 times, to get the different endings, and the ability to forward through parts you've already read makes it a breeze. It will stop when you get to a new part you haven't read before. I've looked at screenshots from other users and some of their playthroughs ended up different than any of mine.   I've never really played this type of game but Cinders has drawn me in. Love this game! Now re-take the residence and coozy up with Perrault or whatever path you choose!

It is a very mature approach to the Cinderella story. Interesting dialogue, very witty. There is also gorgeous art and the music is wonderful, it's interesting how one different decision can change a lot of things in the story, and while there are 4 endings, there are many variations to each one.
Beautiful music and stunning art. Must have across visual novels.

There are many things to like about this game, and not much to find fault with. There is a lot of text to read, but the pacing is very nice, and is written like an interesting book. The illustration is fantastic; the artist makes stunningly attractive people which make the game very very easy on the eyes. The story is familiar, but has enough of a spin to keep it fresh. There is not action, per se, but there is drama. Enjoyed it, and I intend on re-visiting it so that I can explore some alternate endings. The only complaint I can find with this game at this moment is the price. at a $20 usd price point, it does not present a good value. [ 7 / 10 ]

What a delightful game! The only virtual novels I have done are the 'choose your own adventure' novels for children on Amazon. I remember these types of books from my childhood where it would have you turn to a certain page. I must be showing my age LOL! I liked the graphics, the storyline, and the fact that it has such replayability. It takes 3.5 hours to complete, just as comparison since I don't notice anyone else mentioning that.

I absolutely love reading, so for me, this made the game all the more interesting. While the story of Cinderella has never been one of my favorite fairy-tales, this isn't the typical Cinderella story. While there are elements of Cinderella, I believe they took her story and twisted it to be what it should REALLY be like. My boyfriend bought me this game as a Christmas present, but I've honestly played it more than some of the other games in my list. The replayability is phenomenal, although you'll eventually get tired of answering the same questions over and over. There are several different endings, and I mean SEVERAL. I've gotten all of the achievements and even went back over and over to try and get the different endings. If you don't make a strategy to follow the line of questioning to lead you to a certain ending, you may not get it..so try, try again!  AND SPAM THE CTRL BUTTON IF YOU RE-PLAY. It gets tedious reading the same stuff over and over. But the story is absolutely stunning!  Replayability - 10/10 Achievements (Some are tough to get if you don't strategize..fair warning) - 10/10 Story - 10/10 Price - Try to get it when it's on sale. I love the game, but I'm not sure I'd pay the $14 + that they're asking for. No offense to the company.  Determination to get EVERY ending and EVERY possibility - PRICELESS <3

Cinders, a twist on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, is all about its characters. It has all the elements of Cinderella: A ball, a prince you can pursue, evil stepsisters and stepmother, and a fairy godmother. However, Cinders herself is a strong, optimistic, and self-reliant woman capable of taking her future into her own hands. Her stepsisters and stepmother are well developed characters that you can get to know and maybe even understand. The fairy godmother isn't perfect and neither is the prince. Add to that the Captain, the town witch, and Cinder's old friend the merchant, and you have a variety of extremely interesting characters with their own stories and complicated relations to you and each other. Throughout the game, your interactions with them and your decisions for Cinders helps her decide which path to freedom to take. Each broad ending has a variety of unique and lovely sub-types.  If this hasn't told you this game is worth playing, then add to that the lovely artwork with small background animations and very realistic and expressive character art, the beautiful music, and the tiny fact that the dialogue speed matches the speed of the character speaking. This last fact really helps you mentally hear how people are speaking. Honestly, it's as close as you can get to voice acting without actually having voice acting in it.  tl;dr Go play Cinders. It's amazing. 10/10

If you like visual novels, Cinders is definitely worth checking out. Not only are the visuals astounding, but the writing is solid. It's an overall fun, mature (but *no nudity!*) twist on the Cinderella story. The characters have great depth (depending on how you play the game), and there's several differnet paths and combinations you can take that maximize the playthrough value.   One aspect that might be frustrating is that the game does not make obvious what the different personality choices are coded as. For example, is the choice you picked 'good,' 'bad,' or 'naive?' The lack of labelling makes the game a bit more challenging to get all the endings. If you are looking for a quick playthrough for 100% completion, you may have to go online if you don't want to do it through trial and error.  Overall amazing game with great relationships, story, and visuals. Highly recommended for those who like VNs or those who are looking to get into the VNs.

This is pretty much as good as VNs get, and highly recommended if you like them or if you just want a modern, feminist and grown-up take on a classic fairy-tale. Cinders offers a lot of options and a wide variety of different endings. It also has good writing, and a fantastic score and art. I've achieved all the endings and they're all quite satisfactory (even when they're sad). Highly recommended and you'll get a lot of game-play out of this VN!

An awesome game! Probably the best graphic novel/dating sim that I've ever played.   I like that all the characters in this game have depth, even the supposed villains. And while there's a number of people you can 'date', you have to be very clear on your path with them to get the best endings. There are also paths where you don't end up with anyone at all. All of your actions really do have consequences.   The game is extremely well made. The graphics are stunning and the background sounds work well. The game runs very smoothly and so far, every storyline I've played has been enjoyable.   There were a few times in the game where I felt the dialogue got a bit preachy. The writers obviously really wanted to push the idea that Cinders was strong and independent, but at times it was like they were beating you over the head with it. Don't get me wrong, I love this game and I LOVE the fact that it actually has a strong female protagonist and that the goal of the game isn't necessarily to end up with a man. I think a little bit of subtlety would have gone a long way.
This is a great game, i love the art work and the story, but it is pretty difficult, I tried few times but only got half good ending, not a totally perfect happy ending

Lovely graphic novel/choose your own adventure. We all know cinderella, but what would you do if you were in her glass slippers. Now you can find out. Some of the subtitles are...rough, but all in all, it was lovely.
This game has such an irresistible charm to it, from the art to the choices you make. I always enjoy coming back to this game, and it has become one of my favourites.
Features a truly stunning presentation of highly dynamic graphics and excellent sound design - likely the best of any visual novel, period.

Cinders is a visual novel retelling the classic Cinderella fairy tale. What makes is worthwhile is its treatment of all of the characters as complex human beings. The stepmother and sisters aren't evil for the sake of being evil, but are flawed creatures that have a dificult time comprehending that being genuinely nice to people is a viable method of surviving in the world.  If you've ever wanted the chance to redeem the villains from this fairy tale, give Cinders a try.

I waited for this game to go on sale because I think the price is a little ridiculous. But for $10? This game is definitely worth it.  The story and art are incredible to say the least. The many different paths and endings you can achieve give the game a high level of replayability, along with the the ever so hand 'skip' button (which stops automatically whenever you encounter a new scene or piece of dialogue you haven't seen before.)  This is a visual novel where your choices really do matter. Every component of your relationships with other characters and personal character choices influence the ending you receive. My only complaint is that the price is a little steep, and I was lucky to have gotten this game while it was on sale.  10/10 I would reccomend this to all lovers of visual novels, fairy tales, and dark stories. This isn't your average fairy tale :)

If you've never played a visual novel, and you're interested in doing so, this isn't a bad option to start with. The artwork is stunning, and the secondary characters well rounded and nuanced if you delve into their stories. I didn't care that much for the protagonist, and was generally more interested in the secondary characters, but it didn't stop me from enjoying the game overall.  I played through a number of times within 8 hours, unlocking all the achievements. However, I only got 1 card drop in that time, and have had to run the game since then to get the remainder of my cards.

Basically, it's a choose your own adventure novel.  On that note, I now know that if I were Cinderella, I'd kill my stepsisters with kindness, upstage them at the ball, then say 'screw the prince' and run away with his knight instead.  ... Clearly, this is information I needed to know about myself.

I've only been playing for a while and this is very entertaining. The writing and personality of the characters are amazing. I might be making choices that I would have made in reality but the way the story takes that is very very interesting indeed.
Are you tired of anime art styled and main characters that are as dumb as a doornob Visial novles Like I am? Then this visial novle is for you! The art is VERy pretty. The story is great.

I loved the art and music in this visual novel. The family characterization makes subsequent play throughs interesting. I could not have cared less about the love interests in this game. However, better skipping between choices after replays would have kept the completionist in me happy. I couldn't bring myself to play through every ending. I also wish I wasn't forced to go through the ball every playthrough. As it is, I didn't finish all paths.
Lovely artwork, great story, and dialogue.

It is a very interesting story, my first playthrough I actually used my own opinion and funny enough I ended up the lonely traveler, like I would be. Because I was close to P but didn't dare to ask him. And after that I found it interesting to find all the other senario's becausse I could roleplay them.
Amazing game, with beautiful art and music, and LOTS of decisions and endings.  Recommended for all visual novel and interactive story fans!

NOW YOU CAN EXPERIENCE ONE OF THE HANDFUL OF VISUAL NOVELS THAT MAKES YOU GO STUPID OVER ALL THE PRETTY ARTS LOOK AT THOSE ARTS OKAY, LOOKING TIME IS OVER NOW PLAY AS CINDERELLA WITH A COOLER NAME CONNECT WITH YOUR CUTE SISTERS OR JUST CHASE AFTER BOYS USE ROLEPLAY CHOICES TO SHAPE YOUR PERSONALITY WONDER WHY NO PUMPKINS TURNED INTO A CARRIAGE EXPERIENCE A STORY LIKE NO OTHER FAIRYTALE RETELLING BUT THEN DISREGARD EVERYTHING FOR THE ARTS
'its ok. needs less talking. more guns and explosions. i give it a 10/10' - ign

If you are here because of the RPG tag then best move on as this game have nothing what differs a RPG from a Adventure. Cinders is a pure Vissual Novel with nice graphics but if you expect some kind of character system as some other VN have then there is nothing. The RPG flag was for me the main reason to upvote this game in greenlight but if developer consider games that have some choices that influence the ending already as RPG then over 50% of all games can be considered be a RPG.

I hated it. It's like a hidden objects game without any hidden objects or puzzles, and tons of talking with NO VOICE-OVERS. I know, I know, that's what it is: and interactive novel. But the interaction is so minimal that I felt like falling asleep in between each 'interaction'... I thought maybe it would be like those books where we're the hero, picking our way at every corner, but no. It's talk, talk, talk, talk, talk, and talk some more... zzzz... Oh! Do I get to make a choice?! Let's see: 'Ask to know more about him?' Uh... no, thanks. I've heard enough already... After only 20 minutes I already didn't care one way or another.  It's not that it's bad (although it's WAY overpriced for what it is). The graphics area beautiful, but there aren't that many scenes -- actually a LOT less than in your average hidden objects games -- but I found the 'game' boring, the story boring, and, like I said, there's not even voice-overs to keep you awake. I see we can play it again to get a different ending. I'll pass, thank you very much.

This is a great visual novel game with multiple endings and a variety of different paths to choose from as you play.  The artwork is gorgeous, both the character designs and particularly the background scenery are very impressive.  The soundtrack is great too with a wide range of pieces that draw out a variety of emotions suited to each scene, from tense moments to quiet peaceful mornings.  The dialog is pretty solid and well written, I've definitely seen a lot worse in these kinds of games. The plot of the story is great, holds a lot of mystery and introduces a variety of interesting and distinct characters. With the varied endings, multiple playthroughs can be drastically different depending on the choices you make.  I've only finished the game once and am on my second playthrough at the time of writing this review, but there are at least 3 possible 'romantic interests' for Cinders to end up with that I can see, perhaps more that I have not realized yet.  The dialog choices are interesting because it really feels like you get to shape the kind of personality that Cinders has, whether you choose to make her defiant and rebellious or more meek and complacent, or something in between. There is a lot of variety here and it helps create greater depth and adds to the replayability.  Even if you haven't ever really played visual novel games before, Cinders would be a great choice to break into the genre. It has a lot to offer and does a lot of things well.
It's a cool twist in Cinderella. I liked it
